title: Tuesday, 23rd February, 2016

11:14 am
BE

We've gone through, what, at least a decade of mining companies switching to regional management then back to product-led management then back to regional management.

BE

Which is better generally? Dunno. Which is better for BHP? Dunno. Will this make BHP better? Dunno. Might it make worse? Dunno.

BE

Have some sellside. Here's Jefferies.

11:15 am
BE

BHP reported 1H FY16 EBITDA that was 11% lower than we had anticipated.
More importantly, the company announced a new management structure,
capex reductions, planned productivity gains, a new dividend policy, and clear
capital allocation priorities. These changes are aimed at freeing up cash and
should therefore be a positive for BHP shares. We expect the company to use its
financial flexibility to acquire an asset (most likely in copper) in the near term.

BE

Management shakeup: In an effort to simplify and in some ways decentralize its
structure, BHP announced that it will now group its mining assets into two segments -
Minerals Australia, to be run by Mike Henry, and Minerals Americas, to be run by Danny
Malchuk. Global Petroleum will be run by Steve Pastor. BHP President of Iron Ore, Jimmy
Wilson, and President of Petroleum, Tim Cutt, are leaving the company. We expect this to
all be a relatively seamless transition, and the end result should be further cost cutting as
redundant functions throughout BHP are eliminated. Tough times call for tough measures.

BE

More productivity gains and capex reductions: BHP expects to deliver $2.1bn of
productivity gains in FY '16. These gains will be partially offset by a $1.5bn negative impact
due to lower grades at Escondida. The company has lowered its capex guidance from $8.5bn
to $7.0bn for FY16 and from $7.0bn to $5.0bn for FY17. Lower costs and lower capex will
give BHP additional financial flexibility, as will its new dividend policy (see below).
An end to the progressive dividend, as expected: BHP has lowered its interim
dividend by 74%, from $0.62/sh to $0.16/sh (implies an annualized dividend of $1.7bn and
dividend yield of 2.8%). We had expected at least a 50% cut to the dividend. The announced
$0.16/sh 1H dividend is covered by FCF. Going forward, BHP's dividend will be based on
a payout ratio (rather than a progressive policy), with the dividend equal to a minimum of
50% of Underlying attributable profit. This implies a minimum FY17 dividend of $0.18/sh
(1.6% yield) if we assume current spot commodity prices and FX. The new policy will ensure
that capital returns from BHP are linked to the cyclicality of the business.

11:15 am
BE

Clear capital allocation priorities: BHP's capital allocation priorities will be to 1) spend
maintenance capital, 2) maintain a strong balance sheet, and then 3) pay the new minimum
dividend. Excess free cash flow will then be allocated to either debt reduction, additional
dividends, share repurchases, growth investment, or M&A. At spot prices, BHP would
generate excess free cash flow over the next two years (with average FCF before dividends
of more than $4bn per year at current spot commodity prices, on our estimates). We do
not expect debt repayments (reported net debt of $25.9bn would be 2.2x annualized
1H FY16 EBITDA of $6.0bn), share buybacks, significant additional dividends, or growth
investment (better to buy than build now) to be higher priorities than M&A over this period
as compelling opportunities may arise.
M&A may be on the near-term agenda: BHP believes that "depressed asset values and
falling share prices provide opportunities" for mining companies with financial strength.
The company is most constructive on the outlook for copper and oil. If we assume no
change in dividend from 1H FY16 to 2H FY16 and from FY16 to FY17, the company's annual
dividend payment would fall by $4.9bn relative to FY15. This reduction combined with the
announced capex and opex cuts gives BHP significant financial flexibility to buy an asset.
We would not rule out an acquisition of a world class copper asset in the $5bn range, if the
opportunity emerges.

BE

That's Christopher LaFemina, of course.

Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 413.75, down 22.55 (-5.17%), High: 436.30, Low: 383.85, Volume: 6.96m
BE

Today, it turns out that StanChart's revenue line is awful. Well below consensus.

BE

But 2018 guidance is okay! The restructuring costs basically involve closing half of StanChart to get there, but 2018 guidance is a-o-kay!

BE

Here's UBS.

BE

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: StanChart's numbers were weaker across the board. 4Q15 revenue was 12% lower
than consensus, costs 6% higher and loan losses 6% above for a loss of US$911m
compared with consensus loss of US$229m. Common equity tier 1 capital at 12.6% is
a significant miss to our 13.1% estimate: a particularly important issue for the bank in 2016, a year in which we expect another statutory loss. Capital erosion appears mostly
driven by restructuring costs and valuation adjustments taken below the line. Nonperforming loans rose to 4.8% of the book from 3.0% at 1H15, with NPL cover broadly unchanged at 53% from 54% HoH.

11:25 am
BE

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Capital was weak – CET1 at US$38.2bn was up only US$0.5bn HoH despite the
US$5.1bn rights issue in December 2015. Though FX played a role, fresh capital raised
has already been largely absorbed in dealing with bank challenges – RWAs would have
also benefited from FX. Longer term, the weakness in revenues is the biggest issue
however. Income was even worse than we expected, down 11% QoQ to US$13bn
annualised. This compares with a US$17.0-17.5bn target for 2018 which underpins the
8% ROE target for that year.

BE

Q: How has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: StanChart expects a 'subdued' performance in 2016 but continues to aim for an 8%
ROE in 2018, 10% in 2020. We think the bank is unlikely to achieve its 2018 target.

BE

(@Patience: that's like saying a bus is in better shape than a bicycle. It doesn't tell you much about either.)

11:26 am
BE

And Morgan Stanley.

BE

Quick Comment: A weak quarter with an adjusted loss of $0.85bn (vs consensus loss of $0.17bn), driven by revenues - revenue miss $0.5bn below on cons with Corporate and Institutional 15% light of MSe and retail 5% light. Full year PBT was a loss of $1.5bn includes below line charges of $1.8bn restructuring charge and $900m 'valuation methodology' changes. CET1 of
12.6% was also c.40bps light of expectations driven by higher below the line charges.

Revenue a key question mark - with only $3.26bn of revenue in 4Q 2015, down 27% y/y and 11% q/q and a 12% miss vs. consensus. Annualising the revenue 4Q level suggests $13.5 billion vs $15.5 billion consensus for 2015 so understanding dynamics here will be key for the call.

Impairment still running high with $1.2bn above the line (with another $1.0bn below the line); this is higher than expected though represents an upfronting of charges on the liquidation portfolio. The NPL ratio is up to ~4.8% (with migration from CG12) and so confirmation of an underlying credit cycle is forming.

BE

CET1 at 12.6% 40bp miss to MSe largely due to pull forward of restructuring, TNAV $12.2 also a miss vs. MSe $13.1. CET1 increased 120bps q/q to 12.6% due to proceeds of rights issue but was 40bps light of our 13% estimate despite RWAs coming in 2% lower than expected at $303 billion. The miss here is driven by pull forward of previously guided restructuring charges in 4Q15 (including provisions for the liquidation portfolio) and management indicates that they expect the CET1 ratio to be toward the top end of the 12-13% target range as the liquidation portfolio is run down.
Outlook indicates a difficult year ahead: "Given current market conditions and the early stage of implementation of our strategy, we expect the financial performance of the Group to remain subdued during 2016. We will continue to take the necessary and sometimes painful actions to reposition the Group for returns and disciplined growth."

Targets for 2018/2020 reiterated - somewhat encouraging is the reiteration of guidance for 8% ROE in 2018 and 10% in 2020, which in our view the stock does not price in. To get closer to hit this guidance we expect that management could need to improve the less than $10bn cost target for 2018.

11:27 am
BE

And Investec.

BE

The fact that STAN reported a loss in Q4 2015 is not particularly newsworthy – so did HSBC (Buy), and so (we think) will Lloyds (Buy), RBS (Buy) and Barclays (Buy). However, for H2 2015, STAN posted a loss before tax of $3.6bn, and we still believe that consensus expectations for 2015/16e remain much too high. Some support is offered by the fact that STAN trades on just 0.5x 2015 tNAV (1224c) and boasts a solid CET1 capital ratio of 12.6%, but we still advise any would-be investors to wait for a better entry level.

Q4 2015 revenues of $3.3bn were exceptionally weak - down 27% YoY, missing consensus of $3.7bn by 12%, and 7% below our own $3.5bn forecast.

Costs of $2.94bn were only slightly (1%) worse than our ($2.90bn) forecast and 3% worse than consensus ($2.85bn). The UK bank levy was $440m.

BE

The impairment charge of $1.19bn was in line with us, and 4% worse than consensus. However, the Q4 2015 charge is a 14% QoQ improvement and we continue to believe that Q3 2015 (which included a notable element of coverage build) will represent “peak impairment”.

The Q4 2015 Underlying Loss before Tax is $851m, 58% worse than us (- $539m) and a 242% miss against consensus (-$249m).

tNAV per share has fallen from 1586c at H1 2015 to 1224c in H2 2015 reflecting a combination of incurred losses and rights issue dilution.

As previously announced, there is no 2015 final dividend. We are not currently anticipating a 2016e interim dividend either.

The reported numbers include $1.8bn for restructuring, $0.9bn for valuation methodology changes and a $0.4bn goodwill impairment.

Ahead of today’s FY15 results our EPS forecasts of 6c and 51c for 2016/17e were 25% and 34% below Bloomberg consensus. Our own forecasts are now under review, but we certainly expect consensus to move down materially. We will review our target price in line with forecast revisions.

BE

Here's Cazenove with the summary.

11:40 am
BE

WG delivered a decent underlying FY15 result, with a 3% EBITA beat (~6%
for 2H) and a 10% dividend increase as promised. WG experienced a -21%
LFL decline in revenues (-6% vs cons); however, margins led by Engineering
were very resilient overall (+0.6pp vs cons). WG has done an exemplary job
managing costs with $148m “structural” savings found. The company once
again did not provide meaningful guidance for FY16. The stock should trade
well today, given an oils space where a lack of disappointment is currently
unusual. We like the margin resilience, but think more attractive bargains are
available in the sector right now, albeit with more risk. We are relative UW.

BE

 FY15 result. On a proportional basis, revenue was $5.85b (in line with JPMe,
-6% vs company-compiled cons.) and EBITA was $470m (+4% vs JPMe,
+3% vs cons). The FY was boosted by $30m of one-off Engineering closeouts
and deferred consideration release which pushed margins overall to 8.0%
(+0.3pp vs JPMe, +0.7pp vs cons) or 7.5% adjusted. The margin beat was
driven by Engineering at 12.4% (+0.8pp vs JPMe) and Turbines JVs at 6.5%
(+0.5% vs JPMe). As flagged in December, the EthosEnergy JV was written
down, by -$159m to ~$192m. WC was recovered as business activity
declined, and led to a 119% cash conversion of EBITDA. Net debt closed at
$290m at the bottom of the target range of 0.5x EBITDA.

BE

 LFL sales mirrored by LFL headcount. Before acquisitions, revenue
declined -21% being -21% Eng., -22% PSN and -17% Turbines. Underlying
headcount was down -20% or 8,000 staff. The 9% offshore UK PSN rate
cuts will only affect 200 of 600 contractors, a benefit of ~$2m p.a. (JPMe).
 Dividend intentions remain. WG increased its dividend by 10% as
indicated to US30.3c for the full year (3.5% yield) with intention for
another “double digit” (read 10%) in 2016 (3.8% yield). After that the
company will take stock of its situation, but seems likely to adopt a flexible
payout rather than a progressive dividend.
 Outlook for FY16. No guidance was given except P&L tax rate 26% and
10% DPS growth. In 2015, WG held back on previous guidance until mid
year, and by that time, consensus declined by 20%+. We think WG may
again hold back until the picture is clearer, but we see only 5% downside to
consensus EBITA as likely near term. We raise our Dec-16 PT +2% to
564p/share to reflect estimate revisions.

11:41 am
BE

And Barclays.

BE

Wood Group is a people business and, when it needs to be nimble, it can be, reducing headcount by 20% (4000 people) in 2015 and reducing costs sustainably by US$148mn (ca3%). As a result FY15 EBITA was in line with expectations, despite 2H15 revenues missing 10%. The company has, in our opinion, been aggressive on costs and it appears as there is no let up in its focus. The question for investors is whether the company can continue to offset an ever increasing revenue uncertainty at the margin level, with little guidance given at this stage, similar to what we saw in 2015. Our own numbers see a margin decline in 2016F to 6.4%, at the EBITA level, from 8% recorded in 2015, which may appear to be conservative. However, with revenues under pressure, the margin could very well be off a lower revenue number, suggesting to us that the results will be viewed as neutral to positive, given fears over profitability.

Importantly the company has a robust balance sheet with net debt:EBITA of 0.5x, which has enabled a 10% increase in dividend and allowed the company to signal a similar increase in 2016F as well. It will also allow more bolt-on acquisitions, as has been the norm with Wood Group, enabling it to capitalize on the downturn.

At 12x 2016F PE, Wood Group is not the cheapest in a sector that average 9x. However, with a solid balance sheet and a nimble asset light model, it is the type of stock that investors return to first. Hence we remain Overweight with a GBp770 price target.

BE

BE

Here's Cazenove.

12:02 pm
BE

Persimmon full year earnings are ahead of our estimates and the group has increased its special dividend payout.
FY15 PBT was £638m, 3% ahead of our estimate and 5% ahead of consensus. The special dividend has been increased to 110p, payable in April, vs. Bloomberg consensus of 95p. The group will now pay 110p a year to 2021, rather than paying out every other year. In total the payout for the next five years has been increased by
£860m / 280p a share. On 110p the implied yield is 5.6%. The earnings beat is on margin; the operating margin for FY15 was 21.9%, 100bps ahead of our estimate. We expect consensus margin estimates for 2016 to move up today; on first view we expect an increase of c.5-8%.

BE

 Operating margin increased to 21.9% (JPMe: 20.9%) with second half improvement to 23.0%: The
group pre-released revenue numbers, and net cash, meaning margins are the only key new earnings news
today. We initially expect 2016 consensus operating margin to move up to around the 23% achieved in the
second half of 2015 (although historically the increase of H2 vs. the following year FY margin has been more than this, we assume the mix effect that has driven margin progression in the past to now be slightly lower). A 23% operating margin on current consensus revenue for 2016 would imply a 5% upgrade to consensus
estimates.
 Current trading is strong: ‘Customer activity in the first seven weeks of the 2016 spring season has been encouraging. Visitors to our sites are 12% ahead year on year, cancellations remain low and our weekly
private sales rate is 13% ahead of the prior year.’ Current total forward sales, including legal completions taken so far in 2016, are £1,676m, 12% ahead of the previous year (2015: £1,490m). The group is currently operating from 380 outlets, in line with the year end, but statement comments that the group is still in a strong position to deliver further growth in 2016.

BE

And in terms of the Brexit risk for the sector ..... Here's Deutsche.

12:03 pm
BE

We see 5 key issues
1) Economic impact – confidence in employment is of primary importance. The decision to buy a home tends to be dependent on confidence in employment. As such any impact of exit on UK GDP and as such confidence in employment could impact new build demand. At this stage the national housebuilders report they are selling to build rates rather than demand levels. This implies there may be some cushion of a reduced demand for homes within the selling rates of the national housebuilders. The impact of any Brexit on monetary policy and in particular interest rates is also important - the UK housebuilders tend to underperform in anticipation of interest rate rises (due to questions on affordability) but if rises are because of rising wage inflation then this tends to drive outperformance for the housebuilder stocks over the medium term. 2) Bank regulation – no significant change anticipated. Mortgage lending is a key determinant of demand for UK housing as such the capital requirements and the regulatory framework for the UK banks is important. However with the UK being a key contributor to global regulatory changes post-crisis our banks team view do not anticipate significant change. With strong support from the lenders for the Help to Buy Product we continue to see mortgage availability for new build product as remaining healthy. 3) Overseas buyers may be impacted – unhelpful for London. On a Brexit scenario there remains questions about the impact on overseas buyers of UK new homes (who invest predominately in London). At this time we view other world events have a greater impact on demand (geopolitical uncertainty is key) however we note that the decision from an overseas buyer to purchase a London property is in part influenced by the perception of London as a place to do business. We see a Brexit scenario as another unhelpful factor for London housing demand relative to the rest of the UK. 4) Construction labour – unlikely to be impacted. The UK housebuilding industry labour force has a significant proportion of EU but non-UK labour, increasing up towards at least 50% the more southern the location. However with the restrictions to immigration likely to centre around those claiming benefits we do not see a significant impact for the housebuilding industry– most construction labour force earn well over minimum wage and we understand most do not bring their families and therefore do not claim family credits. 5) Build regulation – not anticipated to see significant change. Over recent years, build regulation in the UK has seen significant influence from the EU which it can be argued adds substantial cost to a new home build. However while it can be argued an exit from the EU could reduce the “red tape” in the sector, we see this as a less likely scenario.

IRVINE, Calif., Feb. 23, 2016 PRNewswire -- Western Digital® Corporation (NASDAQ: WDC) today announced its agreement with Unisplendour Corporation Limited (Unis), and Unis Union Information System Ltd. (Unis Union), a subsidiary of Unis that agreed to make a $3.775 billion equity investment in Western Digital, has been terminated by Unis Union after a decision by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) to conduct an investigation into the proposed investment. Western Digital affirmed its commitment to the acquisition of SanDisk Corporation (NASDAQ: SNDK) and announced that the shareholders of SanDisk will receive the alternate merger consideration as outlined in the merger agreement. Western Digital believes the combination is compelling and will create significant value for its shareholders.

Under the terms of the merger agreement with SanDisk announced on Oct. 21, 2015, if the transaction with Unis Union and Unisplendour has not closed or has been terminated by the time of the consummation of the merger, Western Digital will pay $67.50per share in cash and 0.2387 shares of Western Digital common stock per share of SanDisk common stock. This alternate merger consideration is in lieu of the consideration that would have been paid if the Unis Union investment had closed. The alternate merger consideration values SanDisk at $78.50 per share based on Western Digital's closing share price on Feb. 22, 2016.
